DOC.HEAD: Regulators Approve Gold Options, Oat Futures Options
DOC.TEXT: Plans to trade gold options and options on oat futures contracts at two Chicago futures exchanges were approved Tuesday by federal regulators. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the futures industry, approved the two plans unanimously, 5-0. A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell a commodity, like oats, at a specified price by a specified date. One of the approved proposals was for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to trade physical gold options. That will give the holder of a CME gold option contract the right to buy or sell 100 troy ounces of gold at a specified strike price on the delivery date. A strike price is the price at which an option holder can choose to exercise the right to buy or sell the underlying futures contract. The contract is designed to be a hedging instrument, whereby producers, buyers and sellers of gold can lock in a favorable price for transactions at a later date. The CFTC also approved a proposal by the Chicago Board of Trade for trading options in its oats futures contracts. Holders of such options will be able to buy or sell oat futures contracts on any trading day prior to the contract's expiration. The trading months will be based on the underlying futures delivery months of March, May, July, September and December.
